title: Do writers and authors make fewer spelling and grammar mistakes than other people? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, we make fewer spelling and grammar mistakes. 😉 Actually, the answer really depends on what measurement. Per all words written, including rough drafts? Per all words written in a “final” draft to an editor? Per all words written, self-edited and published (e.g., on a blog)? And writers and authors of what level of experience? Daily writers, occasional writers, professionals? On one hand, we make more spelling and grammar errors than non-writers simply because we write more. It’s like the famous quote from basketball legend Michael Jordan: “I’ve missed more than 3,000 shots.” That’s way more than I’ve missed! So, if you put it into the context of quantity and proportion, and compare writers to all non-writers, I’d say overall we make fewer mistakes. In other words, let’s say the typical person writes 10,000 words in a year that *should* be error free (i.e., not texts or casual emails). Compare that to 10,000 words of a typical regular writer that also should be error free (again, like a blog post), and I’d say the writer’s words will be cleaner. To be clear… this isn’t some self-perspective of superiority or that writers are naturally better at spelling and grammar. It’s merely a matter of practice. I write and call upon a mental vocabulary of thousands of words every single day. I don't have to look up the word parable or acumen to spell them, because I just used them within the past few days. I don’t have to remember to use an Oxford comma (my preference) or when to use a semicolon. These come to me easily, due to constant practice, the same way that Michael Jordan didn't need to think of the mechanics of his jump shot every time he took one. Now, all that said, being a good writer or author is not all about spelling and grammar. In fact, that’s not even the majority of it — and an “industry secret” is that there are many professional writers and authors who are absolutely incompetent spellers or grammarians. But that’s because the essence of great writing is in being a successful communicator. Of course your ability to use the tools of spelling and grammar matter, but it’s far more about your original thought and ability to convey it through the words. As such, writers and authors effectively fall into one of three main categories: teachers, persuaders, or entertainers. Your ability to connect with your intended audience and accomplish your goal (teach, persuade, and/or entertain) is what defines success. Part of the reason spelling and grammar matter less is because we have editors and proofreaders (unless it’s self-published content, like a Medium article or Quora answer). Editors and proofreaders refine the art of the writing — writers are creators; editors and proofreaders are improvers. The talents and skill sets behind each of these roles are quite different. This is parallel to directing and editing in film and video. The director is often the visionary, the creator, the auteur (note the similarity to the word author). And the director, like a writer/author, has an editor to handle the mechanics and details of the filmmaking process — to improve the final product. And last, back to editors… to give them a shout-out… their role is far greater than spelling and grammar. This is widely misunderstood among new writers or non-writers. As I mention above, the editor’s job is to improve the writing to better connect it to its intended audience. This includes structure, organization, style, voice, continuity, and much much more than simply spelling and grammar. In fact, there are different types of editors (or editorial functions) because there’s so much involved in the process. (I did not proofread this answer.😊) Thanks for the A2A! [Answered: Do writers and authors make less spelling and grammar mistakes?]

In sum I’d argue we make many more. I write a lot. Those mistakes heap up over time. Even mistakes relative to the quantities written will probably stack up to an impressive number of grammatical discrepencies per paragraph. I experiment a lot with language. I write first drafts where following my inner mind is such a haphazard race the likes of grammar, nay consistency, has little room in the process - that’s what editing is for anyway. When looking at stuff readied for public consumption I’d agree we’re starting to look at a greater care and attention to well worded literature, but for everything presented to a potential readership there’ll be at least ten things that won’t (nor should) see the light of day, at least until it’s been purged of its worst violations against grammatical decency. So no. I don’t think writers make fewer mistakes. The farthest I’ll stretch myself is mayhap suggesting many writers hold the potential for a greater vocabulary and theoretical knowledge of how conventional language works. That does not, however, guarantee we’ll be consistently using our theory in praxis.

I make mistakes, my grammar is not always point on, that is why we enlist editors, to correct grammatical errors. It truly depends on your vocabulary. I have always been pretty well read, I read quite a few books by various authors, I not only enjoy my books, I enjoy books period. You can establish your own writing pattern. I simply tell a story, my way, I use spell check, I use google for the uncertain, and just keep my story flowing. I do read over my finished manuscript for errors, but I cannot catch them all, I depend on my editor to catch the mistakes that I have missed and she does. We as authors are not perfect writers, but, we strive to release quality books with as less mistakes as possible.. 8 books on Amazon currently, although I am still a work in progress.. Author Dia Stone

Ha! I don't know the actual statistics on this, but I can say that I have a large knowledge base of grammar, spelling, and semantics, and I always make mistakes. I would say that grammar is where you would find the most similarities and semantics the largest percentage in difference. Grammar is meticulous, with many rules and definitions of applied use. When I write I just go..then I will edit for mistakes, of which there always are. Semantics, the linguistic branch that involves meaning, are something that a writer would know well. Spelling is probably subjective, but a writer I would assume writes a lot, and therefore naturally has the most experience with common words. Unless we are talking about research papers or philosophical concepts, most writers use common words.

The answer is “Yes” at least if they are careful writers who self-edit and have others go over their work for them to spot glitches they might have missed. Most published writers have their work edited and proofread by other people. Also, most published writers have a good basic knowledge of spelling and grammar. If they don’t, and hope to communicate well, they’d be wise to learn those basics. I have a question for you: What, in your way of thinking, is the difference between an “author” and a “writer”?

I’m a professional writer. I make lots of mistakes. But I go over my work many times to make corrections. I check the spelling of words I don’t know. I ask my husband to read over my work (and I check everything he writes - he’s a newspaper columnist). When I write anything major, I also have friends check my work. I sometimes hire an editor to go over a manuscript carefully. I was an English professor for 30 years. Here’s what I discovered: “A” students make as many mistakes as “D” and “F” students. What’s the difference? The “D” and “F” students write it quickly and hand it in. The “A” students revise and check it over and over.

Great question. Microsoft WORD drives me crazy with the spell check. Most of my words are correctly spelled, but that annoying green line underlines my words to correct them as well as my grammar. Having said that, I think we writers and authors are regular people who are human, and we make the same amount of spelling and grammar mistakes. But I’m sure many established writers would like to think otherwise.

Heavens, no. Writers edit. Which makes us look brilliant, but it’s only because we’ve (hopefully) run our words through several sets of human and computer eyes before we’ve sent them out into the world. Without editing, we’re as prone as anyone else to mistakez. Or auto-correct. ;-)

Not necessarily, though by the time they finish their primary development period (the conventional wisdom is 10,000 hours or 1 million words), they’re likely to have improved dramatically. But this is what editing and spellchecking is for.

Don’t worry about writers/authors. Keep your eyes on copy editors/proofreaders. They are the people charged with scrubbing errors from manuscripts and drafts before release. These folks are either excellent spellers or unemployed.
If they are any good. It stands to reason that those who work with written text regularly are less likely to make errors but, as with anything we are all human and have the capacity to err.
No, in fact we make more mistakes because we write more. Everyone has to proofread their work after revising it for content, flow, and style.
Depends. If you’re starting out, your educational background will be an advantage. Other than that, no. It is the constant writing and learning about the craft which would make you a better writer.
Less than whom? If you mean less than people who don’t write, absolutely not, because the non-writers, well…they don’t write anything.
